Federal Court
Campbell, J.
February 7, 2008.
Counsel:
Richard Wazana, for the applicant;
Bernard Assan, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Richard Wazana, Toronto, Ontario, for the applicant;
John H. Sims, Q.C., Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Toronto, Ontario, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary. Any footnotes found in this case will appear below end of document.

[1]
Campbell, J.
: The present Application concerns a decision of a Visa Officer in which a dependent of a Convention Refugee from Bangladesh is ruled to be inadmissible for landing in Canada due to misrepresentation under s.40(1)a of the
Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
S.C. 2001, c. 27
(IRPA)
.

[2]
The Visa Officer's CAIPS notes disclose that, prior to the misrepresentation being detected, there was no outstanding issue with respect to the Applicant's age or his family relationships. The misrepresentation issue arising thereafter was due to the fact that the Applicant submitted a fraudulent school record. The Applicant subsequently filed a further school record and stated that the misrepresentation was made without his knowledge.

[3]
In order for an applicant to be inadmissible due to misrepresentation, s.40(1)a of
IRPA
requires that the misrepresented facts be material to the application. Therefore, by Citizenship and Immigration Canada's policy guidelines with respect to evaluating whether a misrepresentation will render an applicant inadmissible, the materiality of the misrepresentation must first be determined (see ENF 2, Evaluating Admissibility, s. 9.3, Applicant's Application Record, p. 97). The CAIPS notes do not reflect any analysis by the Visa Officer on the issue of the materiality of the misrepresentation under consideration. However, the rejection letter sent to the Applicant gives the following reason for finding that the Applicant is inadmissible:
Because such documents are used as evidence of age, identity, and relationship to the family member in Canada, the submission of fraudulent school documents could induce an error in the administration of the
Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
.
(Tribunal Record, p.14)

[4]
As mentioned above, in the evaluation of the Applicant's admissibility, his age, identity, and family relationships were not in doubt prior to the detection of the misrepresentation. As a result, I find that the reasons given in the rejection letter do not constitute an analysis of materiality warranting the Applicant's rejection. On this basis I find that the Visa Officer's decision is not in accordance with s. 40(1)a of
IRPA
, and further, is factually erroneous.

[5]
As a result, I find that the Visa Officer's decision was rendered in reviewable error.
ORDER

[6]
Accordingly, I set aside the Visa Officer's decision and refer the matter back for re-determination before a differently visa officer.
[End of document]

statutes: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act S.C. 2001, c. 27 (IRPA)
s.40(1)a of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
legal_issues: Whether the submission of false documentation constitutes misrepresentation under immigration law.
Whether a misrepresentation is material to an application for immigration benefits.
Whether a decision finding misrepresentation is reviewable error where the reasoning provided fails to demonstrate an analysis of materiality.
The standard of review applicable to an immigration officer's determination of misrepresentation.
The procedural requirements for establishing inadmissibility based on misrepresentation.
factual_background: An individual applied for entry to Canada as a dependent of a Convention Refugee from Bangladesh.
A Visa Officer determined the applicant was inadmissible to Canada.
The inadmissibility determination was based on a finding of misrepresentation under section 40(1)a of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).
The misrepresentation involved the submission of a fraudulent school record.
The applicant subsequently submitted another school record and stated the initial misrepresentation occurred without their knowledge.
Prior to the discovery of the fraudulent document, the applicant’s age and family relationships were not questioned.
The Visa Officer’s documentation did not explicitly analyze the materiality of the misrepresentation.
The rejection letter cited the potential for the fraudulent documents to impact the assessment of age, identity, and family relationships as justification for the inadmissibility finding.

Applicants: The Visa Officer’s decision is not in accordance with s. 40(1)a of IRPA because the rejection letter does not demonstrate an analysis of the materiality of the misrepresentation.
The Applicant submitted a further school record and stated the misrepresentation was made without his knowledge.
Prior to the detection of the misrepresentation, the Applicant’s age, identity, and family relationships were not in doubt.
The reasons given in the rejection letter do not constitute an analysis of materiality warranting rejection.
Respondents: The Applicant is inadmissible for landing in Canada due to misrepresentation under s.40(1)a of IRPA because of the submission of fraudulent school records.

Submission of fraudulent school documents could induce an error in the administration of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, as these documents are used as evidence of age, identity, and relationship to the family member in Canada.

court_analysis: The court found the Visa Officer’s decision to be in reviewable error because the officer failed to properly analyze the materiality of the misrepresentation under s.40(1)a of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).

The court interpreted s.40(1)a of IRPA to require a determination of whether the misrepresented facts were *material* to the application, referencing Citizenship and Immigration Canada’s policy guidelines (ENF 2) for evaluating materiality.

The court determined that the Visa Officer’s reasoning – that fraudulent school documents *could* induce an error in administering IRPA because they relate to age, identity, and family relationships – was insufficient because the applicant’s age, identity, and family relationships were not previously in doubt.
The court concluded the rejection letter lacked a proper analysis of materiality, rendering the decision factually erroneous and not in accordance with s.40(1)a of IRPA.
Based on this finding, the court set aside the Visa Officer’s decision and ordered the matter be re-determined by a different visa officer.
final_outcome: The Visa Officer's decision was set aside.
The matter was referred back for re-determination before a different visa officer.
